messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Ed Stafford is from the UK.
He was the first person.
He walked all of the Amazon River.
He started at a small river in Peru.
This was in the Andes mountains.
He walked to the end of the river in Brazil.
He walked for two years and four months.
He walked 6,000 kilometres.

The Amazon has a big forest.
It rains a lot there.
There are snakes that can hurt you.
There are also crocodiles and jaguars.
So, Ed was not safe all the time.
But he was lucky.
He did not die.
Only small flying insects bit him.
And small insects bit him too.
They bit him many times.

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Factual Inaccuracy. The sentence 'It rains a lot there.' was added to the text, but this information is not present in the original source material. This is an unacceptable deviation from factual integrity. FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6907 is below the required 0.75. The original text emphasizes 'poisonous snakes' and 'constant danger', but your version dilutes this to 'snakes that can hurt you' and 'not safe all the time', losing the specific and intense nature of the threat. The phrase 'survived with nothing worse than a few thousand mosquito and ant bites' was simplified to 'He did not die. Only small flying insects bit him. And small insects bit him too. They bit him many times.', which loses the specific detail of 'mosquito and ant' and the scale of 'few thousand'. Suggestion: Remove all information not present in the original text. Rephrase to maintain the specific nature of dangers and the intensity of the experience as described in the original, while still using A2 vocabulary. For example, 'poisonous snakes' could be 'snakes that can kill you' or 'very bad snakes'. 'Constant danger' could be 'always in danger'.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Ed Stafford is from the UK.
He was the first person.
He walked all of the Amazon River.
He started at a small river in Peru.
This was in the Andes mountains.
He walked to the end of the river in Brazil.
He walked for two years and four months.
He walked 6,000 kilometres.

The Amazon has a big forest.
There are snakes that can kill you.
There are also crocodiles and jaguars.
So, Ed was always in danger.
But he was lucky.
He did not die.
Only mosquitoes and ants bit him.
They bit him many, many times.

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6933 is below the required 0.75. The core message regarding the outcome of the journey is significantly altered. The original text states 'he survived with nothing worse than a few thousand mosquito and ant bites', which implies a successful and relatively unharmed survival despite extreme dangers. Your version 'He did not die. Only mosquitoes and ants bit him. They bit him many, many times' loses the crucial nuance of 'nothing worse than', failing to convey the comparative mildness of the outcome against the potential threats. This diminishes the original's emphasis on the successful navigation of danger. Suggestion: Rephrase the ending to explicitly state that the bites were the only bad thing that happened to him, emphasizing the successful outcome against the dangers.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Ed Stafford is from the UK.
He was the first person.
He walked all of the Amazon River.
He started at a small river in Peru.
This was in the Andes mountains.
He walked to the end of the river in Brazil.
He walked for two years and four months.
He walked 6,000 kilometres.

The Amazon has a big forest.
There are snakes that can kill you.
There are also crocodiles and jaguars.
So, Ed was always in danger.
But he was lucky.
He did not die.
Only mosquitoes and ants bit him.
This was the only bad thing.

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6539 is significantly below the required 0.75. This indicates a failure to preserve the core message and nuance of the original text. While the factual points are present, the emphasis and implications are lost. The most critical deviation is the simplification of the concluding statement. The original text states, 'Luckily, he survived with nothing worse than a few thousand mosquito and ant bites.' This conveys that despite extreme dangers, the worst outcome was relatively minor. Your version, 'But he was lucky. He did not die. Only mosquitoes and ants bit him. This was the only bad thing,' loses this crucial comparative nuance. It merely states facts without the implied contrast between the severe dangers and the minor injuries. This diminishes the sense of his extraordinary luck and the relative success of his survival against the odds. Suggestion: Rephrase the ending to clearly convey that the mosquito and ant bites were the *only* bad things, implying that he avoided the more severe dangers like snakes, crocodiles, and jaguars. For example: 'He was lucky. The only bad things were bites from mosquitoes and ants. He did not get hurt by the big animals.'

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Ed Stafford is from the UK.
He was the first person.
He walked all of the Amazon River.
He started at a small river in Peru.
This was in the Andes mountains.
He walked to the end of the river in Brazil.
He walked for two years and four months.
He walked 6,000 kilometres.

The Amazon has a big forest.
There are snakes that can kill you.
There are also crocodiles and jaguars.
So, Ed was always in danger.
He was lucky.
The only bad things were bites from mosquitoes and ants.
He did not get hurt by the big animals.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.7471 is below the required 0.75. The original text states 'he survived with nothing worse than a few thousand mosquito and ant bites', which implies that while the bites were bad, they were the least severe of the potential harms. Your version 'The only bad things were bites from mosquitoes and ants. He did not get hurt by the big animals.' separates these ideas and slightly alters the nuance of the original statement, losing the comparative degree of severity implied by 'nothing worse than'.

Deviation 1: The MeaningBERT score of 0.7471 is below the 0.75 threshold. The phrase 'nothing worse than' in the original text conveys a specific comparative meaning that was not fully captured in the simplified version.
Deviation 2: The simplification of 'stream' to 'river' is acceptable for A2, but 'stream' is also an A2 word and could have been retained for closer fidelity to the original text without increasing complexity.
Deviation 3: The simplification of 'mouth' (of a river) to 'end' is acceptable for A2, but 'mouth' is also an A2 word in this context and could have been retained for closer fidelity to the original text without increasing complexity.
Deviation 4: The simplification of 'rainforest' to 'big forest' is acceptable for A2, but 'rainforest' is also an A2 word and could have been retained for closer fidelity to the original text without increasing complexity.

Suggestion: Rephrase the sentence about the bites to better convey the comparative meaning of 'nothing worse than'. For example, 'He was lucky. The bites from mosquitoes and ants were the only bad things that happened. He did not get hurt by the big animals.' or 'He was lucky. He only got bites from mosquitoes and ants, which was not as bad as getting hurt by the big animals'.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Ed Stafford is from the UK.
He was the first person.
He walked all of the Amazon River.
He started at a small stream in Peru.
This was in the Andes mountains.
He walked to the mouth of the river in Brazil.
He walked for two years and four months.
He walked 6,000 kilometres.

The Amazon has a rainforest.
There are snakes that can kill you.
There are also crocodiles and jaguars.
So, Ed was always in danger.
He was lucky.
The bites from mosquitoes and ants were the only bad things that happened.
He did not get hurt by the big animals.

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Vocabulary Audit. The text contains words that exceed the A2 CEFR level, which is an absolute failure for this standard. The presence of B1 vocabulary is not permitted. Specifically, the word 'stream' is a B1 word and is used in the sentence 'He started at a small stream in Peru.' The word 'rainforest' is also a B1 word and is used in the sentence 'The Amazon has a rainforest.' These words are not on a standard A2 vocabulary list and must be replaced with simpler A2 equivalents. Suggestion: Replace 'stream' with a phrase like 'very small river' or 'small water path'. Suggestion: Replace 'rainforest' with a phrase like 'big forest with much rain' or 'wet forest'.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Ed Stafford is from the UK.
He was the first person.
He walked all of the Amazon River.
He started at a very small river in Peru.
This was in the Andes mountains.
He walked to the mouth of the river in Brazil.
He walked for two years and four months.
He walked 6,000 kilometres.

The Amazon has a big forest with much rain.
There are snakes that can kill you.
There are also crocodiles and jaguars.
So, Ed was always in danger.
He was lucky.
The bites from mosquitoes and ants were the only bad things that happened.
He did not get hurt by the big animals.

metadata.feedback_text: PASS: The text perfectly adheres to the CEFR A2 readability standard. All diagnostic checks were passed with exemplary results. Factual integrity is maintained without deviation. The MeaningBERT score of 0.8293 and BERTScore of 0.9197 confirm excellent preservation of meaning and fidelity to the original content. The CEFR classifier correctly identified the text as A2. The vocabulary has been meticulously simplified, replacing B1 words like 'rainforest', 'poisonous', 'constant', and 'survived' with appropriate A1/A2 phrases such as 'big forest with much rain', 'snakes that can kill you', 'always in danger', and 'He was lucky. The bites... were the only bad things that happened. He did not get hurt by the big animals.' Sentence structures are consistently short and simple, using only A2-level connectors like 'and' and 'so'. This is a flawless execution of the A2 simplification task.
